content:
Attachment III-C Audit Report No. A-1711
March 28, 1962
C3-62-0918
Mr. R. L. Hirshberg Program Officer United States A.I.D. Mission to China United States Agency for International Development Paoching Road Taipei
Subject: Project Type & Non-Project Type Excess Property
Dear Mr. Hirshberg:
In reply to your letter MC-2923 dated March 20, 1962, we wish to bring forth the following explanations in connection with the acquisition and disposition of Project Type and Non-Project Type Excess Property.
Under the Excess Equipment Project No. 99-471, the consignors are all U.S. military agencies and the shipping documents received are usually not in details and comprehensive, particularly when shipments are made on miliary vessels, as in case of normal commercial procurement; hence check of contents and preparation of detailed lists adequate for purposes of allocation and subsequent follow-up are required. On account of this and also because port warehouse is not a practical place for distribution, especially when one shipment as usual and one package in some cases consist of supplies for use of several agencies, custody of the delivered supplies prior to distribution is necessary. Therefore, as agreed upon between Mission, CUSA and other parties concerned, BES was designated as handling agent when this project was started. No change of this arrangement is thought advisable. As the time required for checking and listing varies with the quantities of arrivals and other circumstances, it may not be practical to ask BES to submit detailed lists within 24 hours. Also, it may not be enforceable to set a 3-day limit for recipients to pick up the supplies unless effective and workable measure, if any, can be taken against default. The planner and boring machine referred to in your letter were allocated to KaHB and PWB respectively, both of whom as well as Mission had been duly informed by CUSA allocation letter No. 1150 under date of March 5, 1962.
As for Non-Project excess properties, copies of Excess List compiled from the contents of a 11 Purchase Orders were forwarded to relevant Government enterprises prior to their arrivals. Requests had been received from interested parties and arrived properties had been allocated to those parties or disposed of in accordance with the order of priority as stipulated in PA 0220.
A report on arrivals and dispositions of Non-Project excess properties has been compiled and submitted to you and a monthly report in the same nature will be forwarded for your reference and use beginning next month.
Sincerely yours,
K. T. Li Secretary General 國史饭 Academia Historica
86

the delivered supplies prior to distribution is necessary. Therefore,
as agreed upon between Mission, CUSA and other parties concerned, BES

and workable measure, if any, can be taken against default. The
planner and boring machine referred to in your letter were allocated
to KaHB and PWB respectively, both of whom as well as Mission had been
duly informed by CUSA allocation letter No. 1150 under date of March 5,
As for Non-Project excess properties, copies of Excess List compiled
from the contents of a 11 Purchase Orders were forwarded to relevant
Government enterprises prior to their arrivals. Requests had been
received from interested parties and arrived properties had been allocated
to those parties or disposed of in accordance with the order of priority

A report on arrivals and dispositions of Non-Project excess

Sincerely yours,
K. T. Li
Secretary General

Subject: Project Type & Non-Project Type Excess Property

In reply to your letter MC-2923 dated March 20, 1962, we wish to bring forth the following explanations in connection with the acquisition and disposition of Project Type and Non-Project Type Excess Property.

Under the Excess Equipment Project No. 99-471, the consignors are all U.S. military agencies and the shipping documents received are usually not in details and comprehensive, particularly when shipments are made on miliary vessels, as in case of normal commercial procurement; hence check of contents and preparation of detailed lists adequate for purposes of allocation and subsequent follow-up are required. On account of this and also because port warehouse is not a practical place for distribution, especially when one shipment as usual and one package in some cases consist of supplies for use of several agencies, custody of the delivered supplies prior to distribution is necessary. Therefore, as agreed upon between Mission, CUSA and other parties concerned, BES was designated as handling agent when this project was started. No change of this arrangement is thought advisable. The planner and boring machine referred to in your letter were allocated to KaHB and PWB respectively, both of whom as well as Mission had been duly informed by CUSA allocation letter No. 1150 under date of March 5, 1962.

As for Non-Project excess properties, copies of Excess List compiled from the contents of a 11 Purchase Orders were forwarded to relevant Government enterprises prior to their arrivals. Requests had been received from interested parties and arrived properties had been allocated to those parties or disposed of in accordance with the order of priority as stipulated in PA 0220.
